sentence: Schematic representations of the implant-implant interface based on SEM micrographs are shown in Fig. 1 b–e.
Schematic representations of the implant-implant interface based on SEM micrographs are shown in Fig. 1 b–e.
Figure 1a shows a schematic of the tribometer configuration.
Figure 1b–e compare the surface topography of breast implants from cross-sectional SEM micrographs converted into two-dimensional traces.
The 1D power spectral density (PSD) curves, shown in Fig. 1f, demonstrate surface roughness feature amplitudes as a function of the spatial frequency.
Representative friction force traces as a function of position for silicone implants tested in a shell-on-shell sliding configuration are shown in Figure 2a.
The friction coefficient, μ, was analyzed across the middle 25% of the sliding path and generally increased with increasing sliding distance, as shown in Fig. 2b.

One potential explanation for the transient drop in friction coefficient seen in the Ra = 32 μm sample from 20 mm to 40 mm of sliding (equivalent to reciprocating cycles 2 and 3) in Fig. 2b may be transient run-in of the highest asperities, seen in Fig. 1d.
Tribological testing revealed that increasing surface roughness of silicone implants resulted in increased average friction coefficients across the shell-shell sliding interface (Fig. 2c).
The average and standard deviation of wear debris particle diameters shed from implant surfaces Ra = 32 μm and Ra = 80 μm were 4.7 ± 9.1 μm and 5.3 ± 3.3 μm, respectively (Fig. 3a).
Representative images of wear debris particles diluted to 0.5% concentration (v/v %) are shown in Fig. 3b–d.
The total volume of debris particles was estimated by the considering spherical shape of particles with the distribution shown in Fig. 3a.
